audio_caption: The clip starts with a female speaker introducing an "overview video" about the second edition of the "Astronomy" book from OpenStax, emphasizing that it is "free to access" and "free to download" for the courses. The speaker then elaborates on how to find the book by searching "Astronomy OpenStax Second Edition" on Google or going to OpenStax.org and searching under the science tab, looking for a "nice bright blue" astronomy book.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker stating that she will demonstrate the online version first, then mentions that a user does not need an account to see the textbook. Her tone is instructional.

A single female speaker begins describing a feature of an account that allows users to make highlights and notes. She explains that, "if you highlight anything" you can choose a color and make a note and that highlights will be "displayed" and "saved". She adds that you can search by colors and print them. Concluding that it's a "really nice tool if you're going to be using the textbook" and that "a lot of students find that helpful," but that not everybody needs to.

A woman speaks in a clear and informative tone, explaining features of an online book, highlighting that "in the search bar, you can just search for anything that you're interested in." She continues describing how to search for solar flares, and that the context of the search results is provided around the search term. The woman mentions the highlighting feature and the search feature are nice.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker discussing the layout of a chapter, mentioning that clicking on a chapter name in the table of contents "opens up all the different pieces." The speaker's tone is instructional and informative. She suggests that the "thinking ahead" section acts as the introduction and that the "next" button allows movement from one section to the next. She highlights the usefulness of learning objectives and the presence of figures and tables. She adds that textbooks are "most useful as a reference" and emphasizes that you don't need to read "all words" at the beginning. There are external links that can provide additional learning, and she concludes that the resource includes "all sorts of cool things."

The clip features a female speaker describing the contents of chapter summaries and their usefulness for reviewing material. She speaks in a clear and informative tone. She mentions that summaries can provide extra, helpful information to deepen one's understanding.

The audio begins with a female speaker discussing the textbook's features, mentioning "further explanation," "articles and websites" that are helpful for projects, and "collaborative group exercises" for deeper thinking. Her tone is conversational and informative. She then discusses exercises and questions to deepen understanding, also advising to ask her questions in discussion or during student support hours. She then mentions questions about textbook formatting, adding that the online version is straightforward with a nice layout.

The clip starts with a female speaker explaining that she is going to show another way to access the textbook, specifying that "that other version, that other way of accessing the textbook is to download a PDF." She proceeds to describe the process, mentioning that it will "open up in whatever PDF viewer" and that it is "just as complete as the online version."

The audio clip starts with a female speaker describing a PDF document and its benefits, such as keeping the file after a course and its searchability. She then highlights differences in the book, noting the table of contents and its clickable links.

The audio clip features a single female speaker in an informative tone. She describes a PDF full of links, some requiring an internet connection to follow and others taking the reader to different sections within the book. She explains how these links can be helpful for watching lecture videos and recognizing the connections between different topics in the course.

A single female speaker with a clear and articulate voice begins by talking about using PDF viewers and their search features, advising listeners that pressing "control and F" brings up a search tool, although it's "not as robust" as the online version of a book. She then demonstrates by typing "solar flare" as the search term and commenting on the search results, observing that the search finds "exactly what I typed" versus the online feature's broader results. She emphasizes that the textbook is completely free and accessible in multiple ways.

The clip starts with a female speaker discussing purchasing or renting a print copy from a bookstore and the differences between color hardback and black-and-white paperback versions. She cautions against buying the black-and-white paperback version and says that the bookstore only has the hardback color version, which is a better value. The speaker encourages listeners to reach out with questions and expresses hope that this was a useful introduction to their textbook, speaking in a clear and informative tone.
